There have been experiments where people select for complexity (in an
information theory sense) instead of fitness...and it is reported that they
do well. It would be interesting to see someone do that here, so you can see
what (selected for) complexity looks like. But, aside from that curiosity, I
doubt it could match humans in terms of producing things interesting to
humans....




Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...
517.214.1060




> From: petar_chervenski <petar_chervenski@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Sat, 25 Aug 2007 17:42:15 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Re: Picbreeder comments
> 
> Evolving such a network (a network that selects the parents for the
> next generation) will be incredibly hard. This is because there is
> some intelligence required to perform a good selection. In TBE the
> intelligence is the static fitness function, in Picbreeder it is the
> human intelligence. In fact, some pictures may be "in order" but
> still represent nothing. Perhaps some pattern recognition technique
> may be involved in the process, but this is still not enough.
> But it is an interesting idea of NEAT controlling another NEAT. A
> population of "selector" networks, each one running an evolution.
> This will take A LOT of CPU time, but it is good for experimenting
> with. 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
>> 
>> Ken,
>> 
>> You had talked (at length...) about the merits of the human-chooser
>> verses the goal-oriented evolution.  I'd like to weigh in on it a
>> little and maybe throw in an idea for how to make things even more
>> interesting...
>> 
>> First of all, there is always a goal.  In one case, the goal is very
>> strictly defined, in the other, it is more losely defined.  But
> there
>> is still a 'goal'.  The goal in PicBreeder is 'makes me feel good'
>> which CAN be defined, it just has to be defined in terms of
> something
>> we can't see, which is the neuron firing pattern in our brains.
>> 
>> My hypothesis, though, is that there is a pattern to our internal
>> choosing of what we like.  And I posit that it may be possible to
>> LEARN it.  Meaning, create a 'chooser' network that also evolves
>> 'interesting' images.
>> 
>> You see, I think that 'recognition' is a key element in deciding
> what
>> to choose.  And I think that the method that we use to recognize
> order
>> vs. chaos could be modeled.  Sure, recognizing the difference
> between
>> two people's faces would be harder to model, but I think it would be
>> fairly easy to learn to model the difference between chaos and
> order.
>> 
>> I'm thinking you should be able to evolve a network that tends to
>> choose (rank higher) images of real-world things over images of
>> random, unstructured noise.  You could take many image chunks the
> size
>> of the PicBreeder output images, all of which have some kind of
>> recognizability and pleasantness to them.  Then create a large
> number
>> of counter-examples that are built out of unstructured randomness,
> be
>> it pixels or blobs or arcs or whatever.  Then evolve a network that
>> consistently recognizes the 'pleasing' images (ranks them highly)
> and
>> recognizes the chaotic images as such and thereby ranks them lower.
>> 
>> When that's done, integrate it into the PicBreeder app as
> a 'chooser'
>> which evolves and evolves until somebody shuts it down.  Whenever it
>> finds something that it likes more than some threshold, it 'saves'
> it.
>>  When it likes something more than an even higher threshold, it
>> publishes it.
>> 
>> I predict that there will be a sweet spot for complexity of the
>> PicBreeder image generating networks.  For a while, as complexity
>> grows, the chooser network will rank the images higher and higher.
>> But I suspect that at some point, that trend will reverse.  The
> number
>> of highly ranked images as a percentage of all evolved images at a
>> particular complexity level will get lower as the complexity rises
>> above that sweet spot.
>> 
>> I would also like to mention that combining such a 'general coolness
>> chooser' with a goal-oriented chooser could be quite interesting.
> The
>> two could work together synergistically to help walk the search
> space
>> faster.  Problem may be to generate that chooser correctly to begin
>> with.  But my instincts tell me that one that is evolved to find
>> regularity in an image and finds 'pleasing' relationships between
>> them, such as the one described above, would be adequate to use in
>> conjunction with a goal-oriented evolution of the CPPN networks for
>> who-knows-what.  The reason I say that is that I suspect that the
> same
>> 'regularities' that make for a 'pleasing' image are the same
>> characteristics that lead to a functional CPPN network.  But I'm
> sure
>> you would know better based on your experiences working with them.
>> 
>> Just thought I'd throw that out there for you to think about.
>> -- 
>> John Arrowwood
>> John (at) Hanlons Razor (dot) com
>> John (at) Arrowwood Photography (dot) com
>> --
>> http://arrowwood.blogspot.com
>> 
> 
>
